channel.title: Java web applet saving data
channel.description: I'm making a java applet for my work and I need to save data or information for the applet to be able to access anywhere and also needs to be able to create new files if necessary. I'm thinking that I need a server that keeps all this info for the client to access can someone explain how I can do this? It's a applet on a website

item.title: Java web applet saving data
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

a-zA-Z0-9 in what encoding, though? And what about when someone wants to enter an accented character or speaks something other than English?

Read full topic

item.title: Java web applet saving data
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:19, topic:554289”][quote author=Bowser jr link=topic=673213.msg4501866#msg4501866 date=1452034214]
The simplest way, if PHP can’t do it for you, is to trim away anything from the input that isn’t an alphanumerical character
[/quote]

This is bad advice, imo.

Firstly, what is an alphanumeric character? Are we limiting to just basic ASCII alphanumerics, or are we considering Unicode?
Secondly, how do we ‘trim away’ everything else - can you be sure there aren’t bugs in your method for doing that (ie. null bytes and eregi in old PHP code).
Thirdly, it doesn’t stop all SQL injection anyway (think ?id=1 or 2 etc.)
Fourthly, you can’t always only allow alphanumeric obviously…

The solution is to use parametrized queries, and nothing else is acceptable.

Though even that is hard with PHP, because PHP likes to fall back onto emulating prepared statements and opening up potential holes there too. But it’s better than trying to ‘filter’ data which is doomed to failure.[/quote]
Alpha numerical [a-zA-Z0-9] . When did that include ?,= etc?
But of course, you should use parametrized queries, and find some other solution if you are outputting something that has not gone through the database.

Read full topic

item.title: Java web applet saving data
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Bowser jr:

The simplest way, if PHP can’t do it for you, is to trim away anything from the input that isn’t an alphanumerical character

This is bad advice, imo.

Firstly, what is an alphanumeric character? Are we limiting to just basic ASCII alphanumerics, or are we considering Unicode?
Secondly, how do we ‘trim away’ everything else - can you be sure there aren’t bugs in your method for doing that (ie. null bytes and eregi in old PHP code).
Thirdly, it doesn’t stop all SQL injection anyway (think ?id=1 or 2 etc.)
Fourthly, you can’t always only allow alphanumeric obviously…

The solution is to use parametrized queries, and nothing else is acceptable.

Though even that is hard with PHP, because PHP likes to fall back onto emulating prepared statements and opening up potential holes there too. But it’s better than trying to ‘filter’ data which is doomed to failure.

Read full topic

It’s quite simple to protect yourself, you just need to be aware that you need to clean any user input you’re using.

item.title: Java web applet saving data
item.dc:creator: @hadlich4 hadlich4
item.description:
@hadlich4 wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:15, topic:554289”]Be sure to protect your site from SQL injection.

The simplest way, if PHP can’t do it for you, is to trim away anything from the input that isn’t an alphanumerical character, and reject any password containing any illegal character. But it seems like the example sk8rdude posted takes that into account.[/quote]

Thanks guys really appreciate the advice. Gosh this is gunna be a pain to learn haha

Read full topic

item.title: Java web applet saving data
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

Be sure to protect your site from SQL injection.

The simplest way, if PHP can’t do it for you, is to trim away anything from the input that isn’t an alphanumerical character, and reject any password containing any illegal character. But it seems like the example sk8rdude posted takes that into account.

Read full topic

item.title: Java web applet saving data
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“hadlich4, post:13, topic:554289”][quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=673213.msg4501862#msg4501862 date=1452028735]
Can you explain what you’re trying to accomplish in better detail?
It’s clear that we’re not understanding what you want to do, and knowing that helps with providing a solution.

Are you trying to save ‘sensitive’ information (Ex: Logins, Date of birth), or just something like session data (Last page opened, current index, etc).

PHP has read/write functions, and can connect to databases. Also, I swear I saw something on connecting php to java using sockets, but I doubt PHP is what you want/need
[/quote]

I am trying to save just username password name and points data it’s super simple but very necessary for my project at work. I need to be able to access this data while on the website and edit it. Basically I want it to be where a person can go to the website type their username and password check their available points then I want there to be a manager login that brings up a different page that gives the manager options to change people’s points etc… so I need to figure out how to store data access it and change it. I’ve been researching a lot today on html css and javascript and I’m learning slowly but surely[/quote]
With that description, it actually sounds like PHP can do exactly what you need.
Add in MySQL for saving the data, and you’re good to go.

To create a “manager” account in the MySQL, you can just have a flag for their rights. Ex: if set to 0 (FALSE) they are not a manager and cannot edit data. If set to 1 (TRUE), then they can. You can create a standalone page just for the managers, that checks the PHP session at the start, and the user data (Like if they’re even logged in/are a manager). Don’t display the contents of the managers page if they don’t have the rights for it, in any way.

Being a little more complex, you could make a single page that holds all of it (Login/registration/managing), however, you’d have to make sure the person can only see what they’re supposed to (Not hard, but not easy for a beginner).

codingcage.com

User Registration and Login Script with PHP and MySQL

In this tutorial we will discuss how to create user registration and login management system with PHP and MySQL in simple procedural way....


Here’s a tutorial (I didn’t really read it) on what I’m talking about. It may be of use.

Read full topic

I’ve been researching a lot today on html css and javascript and I’m learning slowly but surely

item.title: Java web applet saving data
item.dc:creator: @hadlich4 hadlich4
item.description:
@hadlich4 wrote:

[quote=“Miss Silabsoft, post:9, topic:554289”][quote author=hadlich4 link=topic=673213.msg4501804#msg4501804 date=1451927499]
Well its for business needs and Google Chrome has an extension so that you can still use the applets. I guess I’m just gunna create a server and access files from their just like rs lol… but if applets are dead what do we use now then html5?
[/quote]
Well before nodejs gets shoved down your throat by others I have been using netty socket.io https://github.com/mrniko/netty-socketio it allows me to continue using java for the backend and then use javascript socket.io for the frontend.[/quote]

I figured I can manage things using html css3 and javascript but I’m just completely stumped at this part maybe I’m just searching the wrong things. I want an external file that the html file can reference to and have that external file accessible from a specific html file that can edit the referenced file and make changes online

Read full topic

Well before nodejs gets shoved down your throat by others I have been using netty socket.io https://github.com/mrniko/netty-socketio it allows me to continue using java for the backend and then use javascript socket.io for the frontend.

item.title: Java web applet saving data
item.dc:creator: @Tree Tree
item.description:
@Tree wrote:

Bowser jr:

Java web applets are dead, don’t bother with them. Browsers are already cutting support for it and it is a security hazard.

item.title: Java web applet saving data
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

Is the applet saving user-specific information? You’ll have to describe more what type of data you’re saving for us to be able to tell you what type of solution you’re looking for. If it’s things like cache files, those should be saved on a person’s computer, a server shouldn’t be used (of course). Are you certain a server is the right way to go?

Read full topic
